text.0: the dakṣiṇās broad chariot hath been harnessed this car the gods immortal have ascended.
text.1: fain to bring light to homes of men the noble and active goddess hath emerged from darkness.
text.2: she before all the living world hath wakened the lofty one who wins and gathers treasure.
text.3: revived and ever young on high she glances dawn hath come first unto our morning worship.
text.4: if dawn thou goddess nobly born thou dealest fortune this day to all the race of mortals.
text.5: may savitar the god friend of the homestead declare before the sun that we are sinless.
text.6: showing her wonted form each day that passeth spreading the light she visiteth each dwelling.
text.7: eager for conquest with bright sheen she cometh her portion is the best of goodly treasures.
text.8: sister of varuṇa sister of bhaga first among all sing forth o joyous morning.
text.9: weak be the strength of him who worketh evil may we subdue him with our car the guerdon.
text.10: let our glad hymns and holy thoughts rise upward for the flames brightly burning have ascended.
text.11: the farrefulgent mornings make apparent the lovely treasures which the darkness covered.
text.12: the one departeth and the other cometh unlike in hue days halves march on successive.
text.13: one hides the gloom of the surrounding parents dawn on her shining chariot is resplendent.
text.14: the same in form today the same tomorrow they still keep varuṇas eternal statute.
text.15: blameless in turn they traverse thirty regions and dart across the spirit in a moment.
text.16: she who hath knowledge of the first days nature is born refulgent white from out the darkness.
text.17: the maiden breaketh not the law of order day by day coming to the place appointed.
text.18: in pride of beauty like a maid thou goest o goddess to the god who longs to win thee.
text.19: and smiling youthful as thou shinest brightly before him thou discoverest thy bosom.
text.20: fair as a bride embellished by her mother thou showest forth thy form that all may see it.
text.21: blessed art thou o dawn shine yet more widely no other dawns have reached what thou attainest.
text.22: rich in kine horses and all goodly treasures in constant operation with the sunbeams.
text.23: the dawns depart and come again assuming their wonted forms that promise happy fortune.
text.24: obedient to the rein of law eternal give us each thought that more and more shall bless us.
text.25: shine thou on us today dawn swift to listen with us be riches and with chiefs who worship.
